articles.headline: Acrimony Reigns Among Republicans
articles.snippet: The candidates have traded attacks in Florida, where Tuesday’s vote could produce a clear G.O.P. front-runner.
articles.abstract: The candidates have traded attacks in Florida, where Tuesday’s vote could produce a clear G.O.P. front-runner.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla.  The Republican contest for Florida ended in acrimony on Monday as the two leading candidates traded attacks, aggressively courting voters across the Florida peninsula in a primary battle that could produce a clear front-runner for the party’s presidential nomination before a virtual national primary next week.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Michael Luo

articles.headline: Bush, Facing Troubles, Focuses on War and Taxes
articles.snippet: President Bush used his final State of the Union address to call for passage of his tax rebate package and patience in Iraq.
articles.abstract: President Bush used his final State of the Union address to call for passage of his tax rebate package and patience in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Facing an unstable economy and an unfinished war, President Bush used his final State of the Union address Monday night to call for quick passage of his tax rebate package, patience in Iraq and a modest concluding agenda that includes $300 million in scholarship money for low-income children in struggling schools.

articles.headline: French Inquiry: Bank’s Inaction Grows as Issue
articles.snippet: Société Générale’s management is under fresh scrutiny after Jérôme Kerviel said that his trading began in 2005.
articles.abstract: Société Générale’s management is under fresh scrutiny after Jérôme Kerviel said that his trading began in 2005.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  The credibility of Société Générale’s management came under fresh scrutiny Monday after Jérôme Kerviel told French prosecutors that his fictitious trading started as far back as 2005  a year earlier than the bank had acknowledged.
articles.byline: By Nicola Clark and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: Illegal Globally, Bail for Profit Remains in U.S.
articles.snippet: Bail bondsmen, who post bail for people accused of crimes in exchange for a fee, are all but unknown outside the U.S.
articles.abstract: Bail bondsmen, who post bail for people accused of crimes in exchange for a fee, are all but unknown outside the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Wayne Spath is a bail bondsman, which means he is an insurance salesman, a social worker, a lightly regulated law enforcement agent, a real estate appraiser  and a for-profit wing of the American justice system.

articles.headline: Sears’ Chairman Will Take a Step Back
articles.snippet: Edward S. Lampert has a new strategy for Sears: less Edward S. Lampert, humbly admitting that  his  style and strategy for Sears and Kmart are not working.
articles.abstract: Edward S. Lampert has a new strategy for Sears: less Edward S. Lampert, humbly admitting that  his  style and strategy for Sears and Kmart are not working.
articles.lead_paragraph: Edward S. Lampert has a new strategy for Sears: less Edward S. Lampert.

articles.headline: Perception and Irony at Davos
articles.snippet: There was a distinct feeling at the World Economic Forum that private equity was not on the hot seat — at least not as Topic A among the world’s economists and financiers.
articles.abstract: There was a distinct feeling at the World Economic Forum that private equity was not on the hot seat — at least not as Topic A among the world’s economists and financiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland  “Behind every great fortune there is a great crime,” David M. Rubenstein said with a sardonic smile.

articles.headline: Germany Confronts Holocaust Legacy Anew
articles.snippet: The 75th anniversary of the day Hitler took power has prompted a new round of soul-searching in Germany.
articles.abstract: The 75th anniversary of the day Hitler took power has prompted a new round of soul-searching in Germany.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN  Most countries celebrate the best in their pasts. Germany unrelentingly promotes its worst.

articles.headline: Can a Sandwich Be Slandered?
articles.snippet: As Subway strikes back at mockery in a Quiznos-sponsored video contest, it has sparked a novel legal question: Who’s liable for the videos’ claims?
articles.abstract: As Subway strikes back at mockery in a Quiznos-sponsored video contest, it has sparked a novel legal question: Who’s liable for the videos’ claims?
articles.lead_paragraph: Some companies have made a sport of using advertising to bash a competing brand: Pepsi and Coke, Colgate and Crest, Miller Lite and Bud Light.

articles.headline: Wall Street Journal’s New Direction Will Take It to Midtown
articles.snippet: The paper that has chronicled business from Lower Manhattan for 119 years plans to start a sports page and move to the News Corporation’s Midtown offices.
articles.abstract: The paper that has chronicled business from Lower Manhattan for 119 years plans to start a sports page and move to the News Corporation’s Midtown offices.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal miles away from Wall Street? Covering sports?

articles.headline: A Quest for Glory and a Bonus Ends in Disgrace
articles.snippet: The Société Générale worker who cost the French bank $7 billion in bad trades told investigators that all he wanted was to be respected, and to earn a big bonus.
articles.abstract: The Société Générale worker who cost the French bank $7 billion in bad trades told investigators that all he wanted was to be respected, and to earn a big bonus.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  When Daniel Bouton, the chief executive of Société Générale, announced that the venerable bank had lost more than $7 billion in unwinding the positions of a rogue trader, he called the culprit “a terrorist.”
articles.byline: By Doreen Carvajal and James Kanter

articles.headline: High Enthusiasm Propels Democrats
articles.snippet: Democratic voter turnout has greatly exceeded the Republican showing so far, but the meaning for the election is in dispute.
articles.abstract: Democratic voter turnout has greatly exceeded the Republican showing so far, but the meaning for the election is in dispute.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The race for the Democratic presidential nomination may have its divisive moments, but it is generating intense interest and enthusiasm among the party’s rank and file: significantly greater, by several measures, than the Republican contest, political experts say.
